newsitem.title: ITALY: Prodi says economy plan puts Italy on road to EMU.
newsitem.headline: Prodi says economy plan puts Italy on road to EMU.

text.p: Italy's cabinet approved three-year economic targets on Friday and Prime Minister Romano Prodi said the plan was tailored to ensure the country makes it into the first wave of Europe's single currency.

He told a news conference the government planned to cut the 1998 budget deficit by 25 trillion lire ($15 billion) to achieve a deficit to Gross Domestic Product (GDP) ratio of 2.8 percent, below the three precent target for the single currency.

The plan would ensure that Italy would have its "cards in order" when the European Union decides next year which countries qualify for economic and monetary union (EMU) at its planned start date in January 1999.
He said the 1998 deficit reductions would be achieved through 10 trillion lire of additional revenue and 15 trillion lire of cuts.
The economic targets for 1998-2000 are contained in a document known as the DPEF which the centre-left cabinet approved at a two-and-a-half hour meeting.
Prodi said the target for 1998 on GDP growth was 2.0 percent and the forecast for 1998 inflation was 1.8 percent.
